  • Tacrolimus is a critical medication in preventing organ transplant rejection, its concomitant use with other nephrotoxic agents can significantly increase the risk of renal dysfunction.

questions.text: The following test is used for the assessment of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stereopsis

 

  • True: Stereopsis refers to the perception of depth and three-dimensional structure obtained from binocular vision.
  • Stereopsis testing assesses the ability of both eyes to work together and perceive depth by presenting slightly different images to each eye and analyzing how well the brain fuses them into a single three-dimensional image.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Color vision: False: Color vision testing evaluates the ability to perceive and differentiate between colors. It is typically assessed using various color plates, such as the Ishihara color test, which contains patterns composed of colored dots that are arranged to form numbers or shapes visible only to individuals with normal color vision.

 

Option C. Visual field: False, Visual field testing measures the extent of the area visible to an individual while looking straight ahead. It assesses the peripheral vision and is commonly used to detect abnormalities such as blind spots, tunnel vision, or peripheral field loss, which may indicate underlying eye conditions or neurological disorders.

 

Option D. Visual acuity: False, Visual acuity testing evaluates the clarity and sharpness of vision by assessing the ability to distinguish details of objects at a specific distance. It is typically measured using Snellen charts or other optotypes and is expressed as a fraction representing the ratio of the distance at which the test is performed to the distance at which the smallest optotype is normally visible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stereopsis testing assesses the ability to perceive depth and three-dimensional structure through binocular vision, which involves presenting slightly different images to each eye and analyzing how well the brain fuses them into a single three-dimensional image.
  • Color vision, visual field, and visual acuity testing are separate assessments that evaluate different aspects of vision, including color perception, peripheral vision, and visual clarity, respectively.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with significant weight gain, menstrual irregularities including recent amenorrhea, and newly diagnosed hypertension. To evaluate the underlying cause of her symptoms, which of the following tests would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexa suppression test

 

  • The symptoms described in the 28-year-old woman — significant weight gain, menstrual irregularities, recent amenorrhea, and newly diagnosed hypertension — are suggestive of Cushing's syndrome.
  • Cushing's syndrome is characterized by excess cortisol production, and the dexamethasone suppression test (Dexa suppression test) is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test.
  • This test measures how the patient's cortisol levels respond to dexamethasone, a synthetic glucocorticoid.
  • In normal individuals, dexamethasone suppresses cortisol production, but in patients with Cushing's syndrome, cortisol levels may not adequately suppress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum electrolytes: Serum electrolytes, while important, are not as specific for the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome.

 

Option C. Plasma testosterone and ultrasound: Plasma testosterone and an ultrasound could be considered to evaluate for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which is also characterized by menstrual irregularities and weight gain. However, the presence of hypertension and the amount of weight gain in this scenario make Cushing's syndrome more likely.

 

Option D. T3, T4, and TSH: Thyroid function tests (T3, T4, and TSH) are useful to evaluate thyroid function and could explain weight gain and menstrual irregularities but would not typically cause hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The dexamethasone suppression test (Dexa suppression test) is pivotal in diagnosing Cushing's syndrome as it assesses the adrenal glands' response to dexamethasone, specifically measuring whether cortisol production is adequately suppressed.

choices.text: Transformer ratio is decreased after surgery
Stapedial reflex is intact after surgery
The contents of the middle ear that are modified in this surgery develop from 1st pharyngeal arch

questions.text: A patient presented with right sided hardness of hearing. Otoendoscopy and pure tone audiometry were given below. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Surgery is contraindicated

 

  • The presence of schwartz sign in the otoendoscopy picture shows that the otosclerosis is active. Hence, the surgery is contraindicated. (If surgery is attempted, there will be more bleed due to the active disease process and increased vascularity.)
  • Transformer ratio increases because the diameter of the piston will be around 0.8mm. Hence areal ratio (45mm2 / 0.8mm2) will be increased 4 times when compared to normal areal ratio (45mm2 / 3.2mm2). Lever ratio remains same.

 

  • As stapedius tendon is cut during surgery, stapedial reflex is lost after surgery.
  • The contents of the middle ear that are modified in this surgery develop from 2nd pharyngeal arch. Stapes suprastructure (which develops from 2nd arch) is removed. Stapedius tendon (which belongs to 2nd arch) is cut.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Transformer ratio is decreased after surgery: The transformer ratio actually increases after surgery due to the use of a piston with a smaller diameter compared to the stapes footplate, increasing the areal ratio.

 

Option B. Stapedial reflex is intact after surgery: The stapedial reflex will not be intact after surgery because the stapedius tendon is typically cut during the procedure to allow for the removal of the stapes superstructure.

 

Option C. The contents of the middle ear that are modified in this surgery develop from 1st pharyngeal arch: The structures in the middle ear that are typically modified during surgery for otosclerosis develop from the 2nd pharyngeal arch, not the 1st. This includes the stapes superstructure that is removed and the stapedius tendon that is cut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Otosclerosis - Presence of Schwartz's sign, a reddish or pinkish hue of the stapes due to active otosclerosis, is a contraindication for surgery due to the risk of excessive bleeding and the active state of the disease.

choices.text: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)

questions.text: Which of the following anemia causes is associated with a hypoplastic bone marrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fanconi's Anemia

 

  • Fanconi's Anemia is a genetic disorder that leads to bone marrow failure characterized by a hypoplastic marrow, which means the marrow is underdeveloped or has fewer hematopoietic cells.
  • Patients with Fanconi's Anemia have a decreased production of all types of blood cells, which is referred to as aplastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria is a hematological disorder that can lead to hemolytic anemia due to the destruction of red blood cells but is not typically associated with hypoplastic marrow.

 

Option C. Hypersplenism: Hypersplenism can lead to anemia due to the sequestration and destruction of blood cells in the spleen, but it does not cause a hypoplastic marrow.

 

Option D. Myelofibrosis: Myelofibrosis involves the replacement of bone marrow with fibrous tissue, not necessarily hypoplastic marrow, and it typically results in a different picture where there's an extramedullary hematopoiesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fanconi's Anemia is a cause of aplastic anemia, which is associated with a hypoplastic marrow.
  • This contrasts with conditions like PNH, where hemolysis is the mechanism of anemia, or myelofibrosis, which involves fibrotic changes within the marrow.

choices.text: Direct branches of internal carotid artery
Lateral striate branches of middle cerebral artery

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset weakness and loss of sensation on the right side of his body. Neurological examination reveals contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss affecting the face, arm, and leg. Which of the following is the most common cause of stroke involving the Internal Capsule?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral striate branches of middle cerebral artery

 

  • Stroke of internal capsule is most commonly caused by occlusion of lateral striate branches of middle cerebral artery also called Charcot’s artery of cerebral hemorrhage.
  •  It supplies posterior limb of internal capsule
  • Lateral Striate Branches of Middle Cerebral Artery are small, deep penetrating arteries, also known as lenticulostriate arteries, which branch from the MCA.
  • They supply blood to parts of the basal ganglia and the internal capsule.  The lateral striate arteries are the primary suppliers of blood to the internal capsule.
  • Due to their small size and critical location, these arteries are particularly susceptible to hypertension-induced damage, leading to lacunar strokes, which often occur in the internal capsule.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery: Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) primarily supplies the medial surfaces of the frontal and parietal lobes, including the anterior four-fifths of the corpus callosum. Although important for the blood supply to the frontal lobes and superior medial parietal lobes, the ACA is not typically involved in supplying the internal capsule.

 

Option B. Direct branches of internal carotid artery: The internal carotid artery branches into several major arteries, including the middle cerebral artery and the anterior cerebral artery. While the internal carotid artery is a major supplier of blood to the brain, it does not directly supply the internal capsule.

 

Option D. Recurrent artery of Heubner: Recurrent Artery of Heubner, a branch of the ACA, supplies the head of the caudate nucleus and the anterior limb of the internal capsule. While the recurrent artery of Heubner does supply a part of the internal capsule, its infarcts typically affect the head of the caudate and anterior limb, but it is not the most common source of strokes affecting the internal capsule overall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lateral striate arteries are the primary suppliers of blood to the internal capsule.
  • Due to their small size and critical location, these arteries are particularly susceptible to hypertension-induced damage, leading to lacunar strokes, which often occur in the internal capsule.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to OPD with severe cachexia and dysphagia to solids. Endoscopy shows lumen occluding growth at mid esophagus. While he is being investigated, you start him on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). After one day, the patient gets seizures and tetany. What likely abnormality is the most likely to be responsible for the above event?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypophosphatemia

 

  • Hypophosphatemia is a known complication of refeeding syndrome, which can occur when nutrition is suddenly introduced to a malnourished patient.
  • It can cause seizures, tetany, muscle weakness, and cardiac dysfunction, and is the most likely cause in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mets to brain: While metastases to the brain can cause seizures, the acute onset of seizures and tetany after starting TPN suggests a metabolic cause rather than new brain metastases.

 

Option B. Hyponatremia: Hyponatremia can cause seizures due to an osmotic imbalance across the neuronal membrane, but it is not typically associated with the acute onset of tetany.

 

Option D. Hyperglycemia: Hyperglycemia can result from TPN due to the high glucose content in the solution; however, it is less likely to cause acute seizures and tetany compared to electrolyte disturbances like hypophosphatemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sudden onset of seizures and tetany in a patient who has just started on TPN is most likely due to hypophosphatemia, a key feature of refeeding syndrome, which requires careful management and monitoring of electrolyte levels during the initiation of nutrition in malnourished patients.
